subject: RE: [junit] No assertEquals(double, double)?
msgSnippet: ... Because it is to move data in its native format.  I already am representing strings.  The input and output portions take care of the final conversions. ...
messageBody:
> From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbr@...]
>
> Floating-point are messed up. The above method makes a claim
> about precision that Java can't live up to. In the spirit of
> not promising more than you can deliver, it's best not to use
> such a method. You can always use a tolerance of 0, but be
> aware that it's not necessarily a good idea.
>
> Oh, and if you're not doing calculations with the double
> values, then why are they doubles? A BigDecimal has the added
> advantage of not succumbing to the same precision problems.
> Maybe even a String would do. (I hate having to hack around
> the language's inadequacies, but it's a living.)

Because it is to move data in its native format. I already am
representing strings. The input and output portions take care
of the final conversions.

> Then a delta of 0 would be fine. It makes it clear that
> you're not expecting rounding errors to enter into the mix.
> That communicates something useful.

Sounds good. (I wrote it as assertTrue() in the mean time).

>
> >BTW, is there something where we can easily test asymetrical
> >uncertainties? You know, something along the lines of +.5/-.1 ?
>
> Not built in to JUnit, but it's easy enough to build...
>
> assertWithinRange(final double expected, final double actual,
> final double upperTolerance, final double lowerTolerance) {
> assertTrue( actual >= expected - lowerTolerance && actual
> <= expected + upperTolerance); }

Sounds good. I don't need it right now--but will for another
project.
